comment.author: 76204898@N00
comment._content: Actually the Maison Kammerzell. It still exists (and still mostly looks the same)... Photochrom from the LOC P&P Collection: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/trialsanderrors/481033556/]

comment.author: 70251312@N00
comment._content: LOC: Your caption and Bain's both misspell the name "Gutenberg," but yours also adds an extra "t".

comment.author: 76204898@N00
comment._content: Also, even though Johannes Gutenberg worked in Strasbourg (Strassburg), there is no connection between him and the Kammerzell House.

comment.author: 70251312@N00
comment._content: It's probably a situation like that which prevailed in Bonn, former capital of the Federal Republic of (West) Germany, and the hometown of Beethoven. In 1956, I bought a ticket and was given a tour of "Beethovens Geburtshaus" in Bonn. I found out later that the tourist people there were simply trying to answer public demand. Tourists wanted to see the great man's birthplace, but it no longer existed, so officials had opened a half-timbered old pile, and filled it with furniture that Beethoven's parents might have liked. I don't know if they are still running that scam there, or perhaps have found a different "birthplace" to fill the need. . . .

comment.author: 76204898@N00
comment._content: From all I know (and I just visited a few weeks ago) it isn't the city of Strasbourg that claims the connection. It seems to me that Bain made the connection "old + Strasbourg = Gutenburg [sic]". The photochrom I posted is from the same era, and it simply calls it "La vieille maison", the old house.

comment.author: 13877179@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/trialsanderrors] Spooky looking the black and white image.

comment.author: 76204898@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/13877179@N00] Is that because one of the tenants was a manufacturer of undergarments? [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8623220@N02] Btw, it's noteworthy that both merchants on the ground floor advertise in French, even though from 1871 to November 1918 Strasbourg was part of the German Reich. Full-sized version on Wikimedia Commons: commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Gutenberg_House_(Maison_K...

comment.author: 34904489@N07
comment._content:
Wystan and trialsanderrors:

Thanks for the comments.  Agreed that there is no apparent Gutenberg connection to this house. It's not far from Place Gutenberg, and there is, of course, a Johannes Gutenberg connection to Strasbourg, but not to this building as far as I can tell. We will amend the record to note this is the Maison Kammerzell (so named in the mid-19th century). It was referred to as Altes Haus or Maison Vieille as well.
